author: Jonathan W.
title: ADA Liquidity for Ethiopia
description: For those in Ethiopia without access to traditional exchanges, purchasing ADA is prohibitively difficult and expensive.

assessments.note: What are you planning to use the ADA for? Is it just to pay the fee to write the transaction to the blockchain, or are you going to sell the ADA given you you by Project Catalyst and keep the money for yourself? If it is the first maybe its marginally an ok idea, but if the second then you are just asking Porject Catalyst to give you an asset to sell for which you will keep the funds.

It definitely is addressing the challenge effectively, I am just putting 3 stars because in the comment someone stated that it might be illegal, thus, it needs further review from IOHK whether it can be done or not. Yet, the proposal itself is a good one.
The basic goal of the proposal seems valid enough but I was concerned with the legal aspects which may have been resolved but further clarity required.

I understand that buying crypto in Ethiopia can be difficult, but having a fixed amount of ADA given to a single person, who then sells it on social channels, expecting people to trust him that they will receive their ADA does not seem like a good idea. What if something happens and it fails for whatever reason, unrelated to the actions of the proposer, then the whole Cardano community will be viewed as a scam, since this was a Project Catalyst funded project.

I have been asked about how to buy crypto currency previously.
My advice always is to find out for oneself.

Crypto currency is a risky investment and no one should be led to buy cryptocurrency without understanding what it is all about for themselves. Many people often learn the hard way.

Encouraging people to buy any cryptocurrency even if one has a high opinion about it is wrong. 
The proposal will create unhealthy expectations and an unsustainable market that will have a negative consequence for the reputation of Cardano.

Moreover where the legality is unclear and in a country like Ethiopia where authorities can make up rules on the fly it would be wrong to assume the absence of a regulation as a loophole to be exploited. It doesn't work that way.

Moreover the challenge is about creating awareness about the technology and what the cardano can do for the community. Not about cryptocurrency. 
In Africa where cryptocurrency is viewed as a means to subvert the rules, it would be wrong for the community to get on the wrong side of the government.

The plan needs more detail on what you are actually going to do. Also why not set up an actual exchange rather than just relying on a lot of trust to get trades done. There seems a high risk that buyers lose their money in a scam that has credibility by being supported by Project Catalyst

If they will receive a license required, they can definitely do it. I posed a question to the proposer, what is the current state. Waiting for a response, but I suggested withdrawal of a proposal if it can not be done.
There aren't any links included that would attest the team's experience. The plan does not state what happens with the USD8000 after the ADA is sold.

It is not clear why selling 8000ADA outright makes a significant impact on ADA adoption in Africa. Even if the plan is to use the 8000ADA to pay the transaction fees, the case has not been made that ADA transaction fees are a significant hurdle to ADA adoption.

metrics are clear and measurable, but:

what if one person bought all the ada?  

also, what if these client/s are not from Africa at all, just traveled to buy it cheaply (no fees)? There is no mechanism to exclude someone from this service, thus I think there are risks and more complication that has NOT been considered.

While the idea and solution have merit so some extent I don't feel I have enough information to rate this proposal higher at this stage. legal aspects and security aspects will require further thought. What will happen with the Ethiopian Birr collected? I could not easily see this in the proposal.

The goal of the proposal is to sell the USD8000 worth of ADA in-person or through social channels, a strategy that is hard to investigate and keep track of. Regardless of the situation Ethiopia, there will have to be better ways to help people buy ADA than this.

solution: Provide free exchange of Ethiopian Birr for ADA via in person and mobile transactions.
